name: Jimmy Lewis: Totally Involved
description:
Vinyl: VG+
Cover: VG (only because of some small paint splatters on back, see pictures, otherwise very nice cover)

Hotlanta 1974
Promo Copy, White Label

A fantastic album of southern soul, and one that's often overlooked in discussions of the genre during the 70's. Despite the fact that it's on the Hotlanta label – which cut a fair bit of club-oriented work – the record's a great batch of mid and slow tempo tracks with an excellent rootsy soul style, fantastic lyrics, and great vocals by Jimmy. The songwriting is excellent, with the kind of sophisticated yet rootsy sound that you'd get from 70s geniuses like Sam Dees or Sidney Joe Qualls.

name: The Rolling Stones: Their Satanic Majesties Request
description:
Vinyl: VG+
Cover: VG+
[Borderline NM, beautiful condition]

This is the special 100% Virgin Vinyl, Digitally Remastered from original master recordings, edition! Very nice record, indeed.

name: Sanremo 1971
description:
Vinyl: VG+
Cover: VG+

FGL 5090
Italy 1971

The Italian Song Festival in Sanremo , commonly known as the Festival of Sanremo , is a singing event taking place every year in San Remo. They would release a comp for every festival with the winning singers and songs. This is the comp for 1971, which was the 21st year of the event.
Some beautiful music here with some great arrangements.

name: MIles Davis: Big Fun
description:
Vinyl: VG
Cover: VG

Columbia PG32866
US 1974

Big Fun has a very consistent vibe throughout. In contrast to its title, the album is moody and hauntingly lyrical—not entirely unlike In a Silent Way. Imagine the foreboding nature of Bitches Brew, with the primitive and funky undercurrent of On the Corner, but also with the majestic melodies of In a Silent Way cresting the surface. Plus, Big Fun is tied together by a stronger Eastern vibe than any of Davis’s other albums. Big Fun is the work of a true musical craftsman and an even truer artist.
—Edwin C. Faust

<object width="200" height="180"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/IRVvIovxPaA?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/IRVvIovxPaA?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="200" height="180" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed></object>

name: Barbara Mason: Give Me Your Love
description:
Vinyl: VG+
Cover: VG+

A very minty clean copy. Original issue.

Some great love and heartbreak soul here with a tight backup band. Barbara re-records her 1965 hit "Yes, I'm Ready", which in its original form was one of the first examples of the emerging Philly Soul sound. The obvious highlight, and biggest hit, here is her seductive cover of Curtis Mayfield's "Give Me Your Love", worth the price of admission alone. Another highlight, however, is the song "Who Will You Hurt Next" with a great arrangement by Norman Harris. Do yourself a favor and pick this one up!
